description: Probably a back-formation from rorty (“boisterous or rowdy, saucy, dissipated, or risqué”). Originally slang but now in common usage.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand) A scam or fraud, especially involving the misappropriation of public money or resources.
examples: Not all of the projects were bad or rorts; the majority were no doubt valuable to their communities.

verbs.description: rort (third-person singular simple present rorts, present participle rorting, simple past and past participle rorted)

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, transitive) To cheat or defraud.
examples: He wants to change the system for the benefit of all and wants to stop the incredible rorting that has occurred within the prisons system.
